sections.content: The word 'budget' makes most people cringe. It sounds restrictive, boring, and like something only accountants enjoy. Let's change that. A budget is simply a plan for your money. It's you telling your money where to go, instead of wondering where it went.

Forget complicated spreadsheets with 47 categories. We're keeping it dead simple with just 3 categories:

1. BILLS — Everything that's the same (or similar) every month. Rent, utilities, insurance, phone, subscriptions. These are predictable.

2. SPENDING — Everything else you spend day-to-day. Groceries, fuel, kids' activities, eating out, shopping. This is where the magic happens.

3. SAVINGS — Whatever you can put aside. Even $20/week is $1,040/year.

The trick is to figure out your Bills total first (it barely changes month to month), then decide your Savings amount, and whatever's left is your Spending money. Bills + Savings first, Spending gets the rest.

sections.prompt: List your monthly bills. Tick each one you know the exact amount of:

sections.content: Pro tip: For bills that vary (like electricity), use the highest bill from the last 3 months as your budget amount. If it comes in lower, that's bonus savings!
A budget with 3 categories is better than no budget. Complexity is the enemy of action. Keep it simple, keep it going.
You've just created something that 60% of families don't have — a spending plan. That's not boring, that's powerful. Your money now has a job!
